abstract.p: This article highlights some of the mathematics behind weaving. It is an outgrowth of two projects. The first was work with Shelley Rasmussen and students in the UMass Lowell Co-op Scholar program. Students Mary Mereseau, Olivia Demers, and Matt D'Angelo

section.title: Introduction
section.p: Weaving that is considered here is what can be realized with a loom such as the one shown in . The main topics are

li.p: an exposition of how the weaver's draft, consisting of a tie plan, pedaling matrix and lift plan can be combined to visualize the final weave that will be produced, and
an analysis of how harnesses can be tied in such a way to realize a given weave pattern.

subsection.title: Weaving Basics
subsection.p: A weave pattern is created by interleaving two sets of parallel lengths of fiber. Each of the fibers in one set, the warp, is connected to exactly one of \(n\) harnesses, \(n \geq 2\). Each harness will lift the threads that are connected to it. A series of pedals are connected to the harnesses, with each pedal connected to between 1 and n-1 of the harnesses. When a pedal is pressed, the warp fibers connected to that pedal through the harnesses are lifted, forming a shed between the warp fibers that are lifted and those that are not lifted. A weft thread can then be passed through the shed. The weft runs perpendicular to the warp. Normally, the weft thread is passed through the shed with a shuttle.

By performing a sequence of pedal presses and shuttle passes that interleave the warp with the weft, a weaving pattern is realized. Using different colors for the warp and weft makes the pattern visible. In this discussion we only consider "monochromatic weaving."

subsection.title: The Weaver's Draft
subsection.p: A weaver's draft is typically a array of four matrices, such as the small example in . The top left (A) matrix, called the harness matrix, has as many columns as the number of warp threads, and there is a row for each harness. Each column indicates which harness to which the corresponding thread is tied. Each thread is tied to only one harness and so each column has one mark. The top right (B) matrix, called the pedal matrix, indicates which harnesses are tied to each pedal and determines which threads will make up the top of the shed when a pedal is pressed. The bottom right (C) matrix is the lift plan, which indicates the sequence of pedal presses that are to performed for each successive weft thread. The output from is sequence of presses and shuttle movements is indicated with the bottom left (D) matrix, the weave. Some weavers use different positioning schemes in their drafts, but the essential information is the same.

subsection.title: Computing the weave pattern
subsection.p: Clearly the weaver has control over the harness matrix, pedal matrix and lift plan. It is a simple matter of logic to determine whether any weft thread will lie above or below any warp thread. In we derive formulas to determine the whole weave based on matrix multiplication.

subsection.title: Realization of a Weave
subsection.p: An even more practical question is how to specify the harness matrix, pedal matrix and lift plan to attain a specific weave pattern, if at all possible for a given loom. In , we give a description of how to determine whether one can realize a desired weave pattern and how the loom can be set to do so.
